Headline: I Build Businesses, Not Just Brands | CEO @ I Inc. | Strategy, Sourcing & Scale Across E-commerce, Retail, CSD/CPC, GeM & Exports | Making Companies Built to Last
Comment:
The most dangerous thing in business isn‚Äôt the lack of capital ‚Äî it‚Äôs the abundance of it.
Rishabh, this post is a stark reminder that easy money doesn‚Äôt just fund growth; it often funds complacency. When capital arrives too early, it blinds founders to the discipline that scarcity teaches. And when the tide turns, the habits built in comfort become the very reasons companies collapse.
The paradox is brutal: abundance tests character more than adversity ever will. In scarcity, every rupee is weighed; in abundance, it‚Äôs waved. In scarcity, founders obsess over unit economics; in abundance, they outsource wisdom to vanity metrics.
The founders who endure are the ones who treat every cycle ‚Äî boom or bust ‚Äî with the same paranoia, precision, and patience. They understand that capital is not a crutch. It‚Äôs an amplifier. It magnifies either your clarity or your confusion.
And that‚Äôs the deeper truth hidden in your words: funding doesn‚Äôt create discipline ‚Äî it reveals it. It doesn‚Äôt shape the company‚Äôs DNA ‚Äî it exposes whether the DNA was strong enough to begin with.
#Startups #Entrepreneurship #Leadership #VentureCapital #GrowthMindset #FundingStrategy #D2C #BusinessStrategy #Execution #Clarity #Frugality #Founders

Totally resonates, Rishabh Mariwala. Over the last 10 months on Amazon, we got just one 4-star review. Many ask us to list more products‚Äîand yes, we could chase growth faster‚Äîbut we chose process over hype.
Handled 35+ orders worth 10,000+ INR, remained profitable, and stuck to quality, third-party manufacturing instead of dropshipping. Numbers may seem small, but building repeatable, disciplined processes matters more than chasing funding or short-term growth.
In bootstrapped journeys, overthinking or overdoing without a system is the real danger. Growth comes when process meets patience

Headline: Founder at TailBlaze üêï| Building World‚Äôs First Pet-Longevity Brand with Modern Science, Ayurveda and Artificial Intelligence
Comment:
This reminds me of a Gujarati family I know.

The son raised ‚Çπ2 crores for his snack business. Hired 20 people, rented 3 warehouses, launched in 8 cities simultaneously. "Bhai, scale karna hai toh paise se karo!"

His father started with ‚Çπ50K, selling farsan from his home kitchen. Every paisa counted. "Pehle profit, phir expansion."

Very recently: The son joined his father. ‚Çπ80L revenue, 40% margins, expanding to 3 states. Classic Gujarati wisdom got lost in venture capital glamour.

Your point about capital amplifying DNA is pure gold, Rishabh. 
Uncle's frugal DNA scaled beautifully. Son's "big budget" DNA just amplified the waste.

The best Gujarati businesses weren't built on OPM - they were built on "har paisa count karna."

Comment: This. I've seen brands pour crores into performance ads without ever asking... who are we when the offers end? Because the real audit isn't CAC or ROAS... it's character. What do you do when growth isn't viral, but earned? When you can‚Äôt outspend the market, only out-care it? The founders I trust are the ones who stay lean not out of scarcity, but out of principle... who still pick their own packaging or write their own pitch notes even post-funding. Because when capital enters, your clarity should deepen, not blur. And sometimes, the most expensive mistake is forgetting the value of restraint.
